results.title: Emulation of Warlords: Battlecry for PC
results.creator_credit: Strategic Studies Group and Strategic Simulations, Inc.
results.brief_description: As part of the Warlords series, Warlords Battlecry retains the fantasy setting and tactical focus of its predecessors. However, if shifts from the wargame genre that the series is known for to a mix of real-time strategy and roleplaying. The players commands one of nine races – Human, Dwarf, Undead, Barbarians, Orcs, Minotaurs, High Elves, Wood Elves and Dark Elves. True to real-time strategy genre, buildings must be created, units trained, upgrades researched and resources gathered. Unique to this game is the addition of hero units, which can complete quests and gain experience, strength and skills, unlike the other units in their army.

results.title: Warlords for Mac
results.material_description: Floppy disk videogame. Two 3 1/2 inch floppy disks, colour map, product registration card, subscription card, catalogue and manual in cardboard box
results.brief_description: Warlords is set in the midst of the battle to control the Kingdom of Illuria. The player is put in control one of eight budding empires: The Sirians, Storm Giants, Grey Dwarves, Orcs of Kor, Elvallie, Horse Lords, Selentines, or Lord Bane. Each group has their strengths and weaknesses. The other clans are either controlled by the computer or by another player via hot seat play. The game proceeds on a turn-by-turn basis, with each player issuing commands such as to move units, attack the opposition, order cities to accrue gold, build more units or instruct their heroes to explore Illuria and complete quests before passing the turn to the next player. The game is won once a player has conquered at least half of the kingdom’s eighty cities.

results.title: Touring Car Champions for DOS
results.creator_credit: Torus Games and Virtual Sports Interactive
results.material_description: CD-ROM videogame. CD-ROM, CD jewel case and manual in cardboard box
results.brief_description:
Touring Car Champions is based on the Australian Touring Car Championship and the Bathurst 1000. The game features only one track, set in Bathurst, New South Wales. Interestingly, this is depicted through full motion video of the actual track, instead of being recreated or rendered in within the game itself. The video slows down or speeds up based on the player’s speed and the opponent’s cars are 3D models superimposed onto this video.

The game features three modes: The first is Practice, which has no opponents. Quick Race has the player choosing the difficulty of the opponents and racing in a pre-set car. Lastly, The Round is a season-spanning tournament where the player has to work their way up from the amateur division to eventual Touring Car Champion. Along the way, the player can decide what racers, pit crew and car parts to use in each race.

results.title: The Punisher for NES
results.creator_credit: Beam Software and LJN Entertainment, Inc.
results.material_description: Cartridge videogame. Cartridge, plastic cartridge case, registration card, poster, Nintendo Power advert and manual in cardboard box
results.brief_description: The Punisher puts the player in control of Frank Castle, and his iconic anti-hero persona, The Punisher. The game itself is an on-rails shooter, where the player can move left and right along the screen to avoid enemy gunfire but is otherwise automatically guided through each level. Levels are both packed with enemies and destructible objects, sometimes hiding powerups. These powerups include ammo, armour, grenades, and additional heath. The Punisher has six overall missions with a variety of environments and levels within each. Killing all the enemies in a level gives additional bonuses in the next stage, like extra grenades, ammo and an unlimited ‘super gun’ upgrade. The game ends with a gun and fistfight against the notorious villain Kingpin.

results.title: The Lost World Jurassic Park for Game Boy
results.material_description: Cartridge videogame. Cartridge, cartridge case, consumer information booklet, Nintendo Power subscription form, registration card, poster and manual in cardboard box
results.brief_description: Based on the movie of the same name, The Lost World: Jurassic Park is set on Isla Sorna, also known as “Site B”, where dinosaurs were created to populate the original park. As an agent for InGen, the player must recover eggs, DNA and key information on the cloning process before BioSyn, a rival company, gets their hands on it. Gameplay consists of running, jumping and climbing through the buildings, jungles and caves of the island. Getting in the player’s way are BioSyn thugs and a variety of dinosaurs, such as Pterodactyl, Triceratops and the eponymous Tyrannosaurus Rex. The player can defend himself by using kicks, punches and weapons, as well as ammo and health power-ups.

results.title: The Lion King: Simba's Mighty Adventure for Game Boy Color
results.material_description: Cartridge videogame. Cartridge, plastic cartridge case, registration card, consumer information booklet and manual in cardboard box
results.brief_description:
Simba’s Mighty Adventure is based on Disney’s The Lion King as well as it’s direct-to-video sequel Simba’s Pride. The game consists of ten side-scrolling levels: The first six are set in The Lion King and the rest in Simba’s Pride, with some levels ending in boss fights. The game tracks along with the plot of both films and follows Simba as he grows up. Key events, such as the stampede from the first film, make up their own levels. Simba moves by running, jumping and climbing. Jumping can also be used to defeat the snakes, spiders, or monkeys that get in Simba’s way. He can also swipe at them with his claw or, as an adult, roar at them to make them flee.

Aiding Simba in his journey are collectibles that grant extra lives, refill or extend Simba’s health or fill a special amulet. Collecting all five parts of the amulet grants an extra life and opens up a mini-game that can be played main menu. The game also has a mulitplayer element. Using a Gameboy Colour link cable with another player opens up an extramode where each player has to hold onto a star for as long as possible by avoiding the opposing player’s attacks.

results.title: Play It Again II: Games Collection
results.brief_description:
The Play It Again II project aims to document, preserve, and create an accessible and playable history of Australasian videogames and videogame culture from the 1990s.

This collection comprises physical games and hardware donated to ACMI for the project and as well as game emulation files created by ACMI or harvested from external web repositories.

The project is being undertaken by ACMI in partnership with Swinburne University, RMIT, AARNet, UNESCO PERSIST and OpenSLX GmbHt.
This project is supported by the Australian Government through the Australian Research Council Linkage Program. Play It Again II is a continuation of Play It Again I, which focused on the preservation of Australasian videogames from the 1980’s.
results.description:
The Play It Again II project aims to document, preserve, and create an accessible and playable history of Australasian videogames and videogame culture from the 1990s.

This collection comprises physical games and hardware donated to ACMI for the project and as well as game emulation files created by ACMI or harvested from external web repositories.

The project is being undertaken by ACMI in partnership with Swinburne University, RMIT, AARNet, UNESCO PERSIST and OpenSLX GmbHt.
This project is supported by the Australian Government through the Australian Research Council Linkage Program. Play It Again II is a continuation of Play It Again I, which focused on the preservation of Australasian videogames from the 1980’s.

The Play It Again II project aims to document, preserve, and create an accessible and playable history of Australasian videogames and videogame culture from the 1990s.

This collection comprises physical games and hardware donated to ACMI for the project and as well as game emulation files created by ACMI or harvested from external web repositories.

The project is being undertaken by ACMI in partnership with Swinburne University, RMIT, AARNet, UNESCO PERSIST and OpenSLX GmbHt.
This project is supported by the Australian Government through the Australian Research Council Linkage Program. Play It Again II is a continuation of Play It Again I, which focused on the preservation of Australasian videogames from the 1980’s.

production_dates.notes: Games in this Collection date from the 1990s. The ARC research project "Play It Again" (II) will be completed in 2022.
